item.title: G7: Boris Johnson kicks off summit with plea to tackle inequality
item.description: The UK prime minister urges world leaders to "build back better" after the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Covid-19: Calls to delay lockdown lifting, and Delta variant more spreadable
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Friday evening.

item.title: Stop toxic Muslim characters says Riz Ahmed
item.description: The Oscar-nominated British actor launches a fund to try to provide better portrayals on screen.

item.title: Duchess of Cambridge: I can't wait to meet Lilibet Diana
item.description: The Duchess of Cambridge says she wishes Prince Harry and Meghan's new daughter "all the very best".

item.title: Sony Music writes off artists' decades-old debts
item.description: Thousands of artists will finally be able to start earning money from their music.

item.title: Delay 21 June lockdown lifting, urge health leaders
item.description: The government is warned that unlocking in England on 21 June risks the country "going backwards".

item.title: Andrew Dymock: Neo-Nazi guilty of terrorism charges
item.description: Police say that Andrew Dymock's conviction is a “key step in protecting the UK”.

item.title: Kent to turn away lone child migrants from Monday due to "extreme pressure"
item.description: Kent County Council has reached "the limit of safe capacity" 10 months after taking similar action.

item.title: PM pledges £430m for girls missing education amid aid row
item.description: Boris Johnson at G7 announces funding for girls' education after row over international aid cuts.

item.title: Covid: Unvaccinated most at risk from Delta variant
item.description: There have been nearly 30,000 new cases of the variant in the UK in the past week.

item.title: G7 summit: Officer staying on ferry tests positive for Covid
item.description: Twelve police officers are self isolating after one provided a positive lateral flow test.

item.title: Euro 2020: A football-hater's guide to surviving the tournament
item.description: Millions of people will be glued to the Euros, but spare a thought for those who can't stand sport.

item.title: In Pictures: G7 leaders meet at the seaside
item.description: World leaders are in Cornwall for three days of talks - and the occasional trip to the beach...

item.title: Sir Van Morrison: Ian Paisley defends joining anti-Swann chant
item.description: Ian Paisley and the singer chanted about the NI health minister after cancellation of Belfast gigs.

item.title: 'Cooking for G7 leaders is the high point of my career'
item.description: The G7 head chef Adam Handling on the food he is preparing for world leaders during the summit.

item.title: Google buys photographer's shot of seagull eating a chip
item.description: The action shot of a greedy gull guzzling a chip on Bridlington harbour was taken back in 2011.

item.title: Medieval pointy-toed shoes led to Cambridge bunion surge
item.description: About 27% of 14th and 15th Century skeletons found in Cambridge digs had bunions.

item.title: LGBTQ: The podcast telling Singapore's hidden gay stories
item.description: The SG Boys is one of the first LGBTQ podcasts in Singapore - where gay sex is still illegal.

item.title: Where have all the UK workers gone?
item.description: Why are many firms reporting staff shortages when so many people are still unemployed?

item.title: Crowded House's Neil Finn: The most debauched we got was water fights
item.description: Neil Finn on touring with Crowded House, playing with Fleetwood Mac and ruining hotel rooms.

item.title: Andrew Dymock: The neo-Nazi exposed by the BBC
item.description: Raised in a privileged academic background, Andrew Dymock led two banned neo-Nazi terror groups.

item.title: 'Huntington's disease won't stop me having a baby'
item.description: Heather and her husband are going to have a baby, even though Heather's time with the child will be limited.

item.title: Euro 2020 and Covid: How can I watch with my friends?
item.description: Covid rules are making things a bit different for Euro 2020 spectators.

item.title: Crocodile attack twin: 'You have to fight for the people you love'
item.description: Georgia Laurie tells us about saving her twin, Melissa, from the attack in a lagoon in Mexico.

item.title: Why it's the end of the road for petrol stations
item.description: Many petrol stations will close over the next 20 years, accelerating the shift to electric cars.

item.title: Why some say this Nevada town siren is a racist relic
item.description: The siren has been called a "piece of historical trauma" over its disputed link to sundown towns.

item.title: Ethiopia's Tigray crisis: Tragedy of the man-made famine
item.description: Aid workers are still unable to reach large parts of Ethiopia’s Tigray region because of the war there.

item.title: Fact-checking Matt Hancock's Covid claims
item.description: We go over the evidence given by the health secretary on the government's pandemic response.

item.title: E3 2021: What to expect at the world's most influential gaming event
item.description: Newsbeat's gaming reporter Steffan Powell looks ahead at this year's gaming convention.

item.title: Essex and London accents deemed less intelligent, researchers find
item.description: People with London and Essex accents downgrade others with London and Essex accents, a study finds.

item.title: 'Summit security feels like another lockdown'
item.description: The G7 summit is being held in a remote part of Cornwall, and has divided opinion amongst locals.

item.title: Young punishes Root drop as New Zealand frustrate England
item.description: A dropped catch and a questionable umpiring decision prove costly for England on a frustrating second day of the deciding Test against New Zealand.

item.title: Uefa Euro 2020 set to start: All you need to know about delayed tournament
item.description: Euro 2020 gets under way this Friday - and what was already going to be a unique tournament will be notable for several other reasons too.

item.title: Tsitsipas wins five-set marathon to reach first Grand Slam final
item.description: Stefanos Tsitsipas is the first Greek player to reach a Grand Slam final after holding off Alexander Zverev's fightback in a tense French Open semi-final.

item.title: G7 summit: What is it and why is it in Cornwall?
item.description: World leaders will descend on the Cornish coast for face-to-face meetings on Friday 11 June.

item.title: PM gifts photo of Edinburgh anti-slavery mural to Biden
item.description: A framed photograph of an Edinburgh mural of Frederick Douglass was among gifts exchanged by the leaders.

item.title: G7: Carrie Johnson treats spouses to steak, firepits and brie on the beach
item.description: Guide to the G7 spouses, as Carrie Johnson hosts a beach party for the world leaders' other halves.

item.title: G7 summit: A cycling tour of Cornwall's G7 village
item.description: Reporter Nomia Iqbal explores the Cornish village that's hosting the G7 summit.

item.title: G7 tax deal: What is it and are Amazon and Facebook included?
item.description: A deal has been agreed by the world's richest nations to tax global companies more.

item.title: Coronavirus: Can countries pay back pandemic debt?
item.description: Countries around the world have borrowed staggering amounts to deal with the pandemic. But where does a government borrow that money from - and can it ever be paid back?

item.title: How did Bolton deal with the Delta variant?
item.description: Bolton had been "ground zero" for the new variant, but now cases have started to fall.

item.title: Covax: How many Covid vaccines have the US and the other G7 countries pledged?
item.description: The US is set to confirm it will give 500m doses of the Pfizer vaccine to the international Covax scheme.

item.title: Covid: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: The government is yet to decide whether to lift the remaining restrictions on 21 June

item.title: Lockdown easing: Four numbers to look for ahead of the 21 June decision
item.description: The key numbers that offer clues as to whether "freedom day" will proceed as planned on 21 June.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 41 million people receive at least one dose.
